context: Sticking to traditional eating times and formal eating habits is no longer the norm. The value and number of on-the-run eating occasions, both snacks and meals, is increasing significantly. The three meals a day maxim no longer holds true because more consumers are eating outside of the home and at times to suit their lifestyles.
question: Eating on-the-run is increasing.
options: True on the basis of the passage
False on the basis of the passage
Not possible to say from the passage
explanation: The passage directly states that on-the-run eating occasions are 'increasing significantly'.

context: Breakfast, in particular, is now more commonly skipped and those who do eat breakfast are taking less time to prepare it. Consumers are developing more complex and paradoxical eating patterns and demanding products that are more convenient and healthier.

options: True on the basis of the passage
False on the basis of the passage
Not possible to say from the passage
explanation: The passage states consumers are 'demanding products that are more convenient and healthier'.

context: The three meals a day maxim no longer holds true because more consumers are eating outside of the home and at times to suit their lifestyles.
question: Most people now eat exactly two meals per day.
options: True on the basis of the passage
False on the basis of the passage
Not possible to say from the passage
explanation: The passage says three meals a day is no longer the norm but does not specify what replaced it.

context: Process safety management requires a systematic approach to identifying hazards, evaluating risks, and implementing controls. context: Renewable energy investment in sub-Saharan Africa has grown by 35% over the last five years. Solar capacity has expanded the fastest, followed by wind power. Despite this growth, access to reliable electricity for rural households remains a significant challenge in many countries.

options: True on the basis of the passage
False on the basis of the passage
Not possible to say from the passage
explanation: The passage states solar expanded fastest, followed by wind — making wind second, not first.

context: Carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology involves capturing CO2 emissions from industrial sources and storing them underground to prevent atmospheric release. context: Workplace mental health programmes have gained prominence as employers seek to reduce absenteeism and improve productivity. question:
A panel defines two operators:
• ⊕  inverts the shading of every figure  (■ ↔ ☐,  ▲ ↔ △,  ● ↔ ○)
• ⊗  swaps the 1st and 3rd figures in the sequence

Input:  [ ■  ▲  ○ ]  →  Apply  ⊕  →  Output: ?
explanation: ⊕ inverts all shading: ■→☐, ▲→△, ○→●. Result: [ ☐  △  ● ].

question:
A panel defines two operators:
• ⊕  inverts the shading of every figure  (■ ↔ ☐,  ▲ ↔ △,  ● ↔ ○)
• ⊗  swaps the 1st and 3rd figures in the sequence

Input:  [ ▲  ●  ■ ]  →  Apply  ⊗  →  Output: ?
explanation: ⊗ swaps the 1st and 3rd figures: ▲ ↔ ■. Result: [ ■  ●  ▲ ].

question:
A panel defines two operators:
• ⊕  inverts the shading of every figure  (■ ↔ ☐,  ▲ ↔ △,  ● ↔ ○)
• ⊗  swaps the 1st and 3rd figures in the sequence

Input:  [ ○  △  ☐ ]  →  Apply  ⊕  then  ⊗  →  Output: ?

A panel defines two operators:
• ⊕  inverts the shading of every figure  (■ ↔ ☐,  ▲ ↔ △,  ● ↔ ○)
• ⊗  swaps the 1st and 3rd figures in the sequence

Input:  [ ■  ○  ▲ ]  →  Apply  ⊗  then  ⊕  →  Output: ?
explanation: Step 1 (⊗): swap 1st/3rd → [ ▲  ○  ■ ]. Step 2 (⊕): invert all → [ △  ●  ☐ ].

question:
A panel defines three operators:
• α  rotates the sequence one position to the right  (last item moves to front)
• β  replaces the 2nd figure with the 3rd figure
• γ  inverts all shading  (■ ↔ ☐,  ▲ ↔ △,  ● ↔ ○)

Input:  [ ☐  ■  △ ]  →  Apply  α  →  Output: ?
explanation: α rotates right: the last item (△) moves to the front. Result: [ △  ☐  ■ ].

question:
A panel defines three operators:
• α  rotates the sequence one position to the right  (last item moves to front)
• β  replaces the 2nd figure with the 3rd figure
• γ  inverts all shading  (■ ↔ ☐,  ▲ ↔ △,  ● ↔ ○)

Input:  [ ○  ■  ▲ ]  →  Apply  β  →  Output: ?
explanation: β replaces the 2nd figure with the 3rd: position 2 (■) becomes ▲. Result: [ ○  ▲  ▲ ].

question:
A panel defines three operators:
• α  rotates the sequence one position to the right  (last item moves to front)
• β  replaces the 2nd figure with the 3rd figure
• γ  inverts all shading  (■ ↔ ☐,  ▲ ↔ △,  ● ↔ ○)

Input:  [ △  ☐  ● ]  →  Apply  γ  →  Output: ?
explanation: γ inverts all: △→▲, ☐→■, ●→○. Result: [ ▲  ■  ○ ].

question:
A panel defines three operators:
• α  rotates the sequence one position to the right  (last item moves to front)
• β  replaces the 2nd figure with the 3rd figure
• γ  inverts all shading  (■ ↔ ☐,  ▲ ↔ △,  ● ↔ ○)

Input:  [ ■  ○  △ ]  →  Apply  α  then  γ  →  Output: ?
explanation: Step 1 (α): rotate right → [ △  ■  ○ ]. Step 2 (γ): invert all → [ ▲  ☐  ● ].

question:
A panel defines three operators:
• ◈  inverts shading of the 1st figure only
• ◉  moves the last figure to the 1st position
• ◊  removes the last figure

Input:  [ ○  ■  ▲ ]  →  Apply  ◈  →  Output: ?
explanation: ◈ inverts only the 1st figure: ○→●. The 2nd and 3rd are unchanged. Result: [ ●  ■  ▲ ].

question:
A panel defines three operators:
• ◈  inverts shading of the 1st figure only
• ◉  moves the last figure to the 1st position
• ◊  removes the last figure

Input:  [ ○  ■  ▲ ]  →  Apply  ◉  →  Output: ?
explanation: ◉ moves the last figure (▲) to the 1st position. Result: [ ▲  ○  ■ ].

question:
A panel defines three operators:
• ◈  inverts shading of the 1st figure only
• ◉  moves the last figure to the 1st position
• ◊  removes the last figure

Input:  [ △  ●  ☐ ]  →  Apply  ◊  then  ◈  →  Output: ?
explanation: Step 1 (◊): remove last (☐) → [ △  ● ]. Step 2 (◈): invert 1st (△→▲) → [ ▲  ● ].

question:
Study the following input–output pairs, all produced by a single unknown operator:

[ ■  ●  ▲ ]  →  [ ▲  ●  ■ ]
[ ○  △  ☐ ]  →  [ ☐  △  ○ ]
[ ●  ■  ○ ]  →  [ ○  ■  ● ]

Which operator was applied in each case?
options: Swap the 1st and 3rd figures
Invert all shading
Rotate one position to the right
Remove the middle figure
explanation: In all three examples, the 1st and 3rd figures swap positions while the 2nd stays in place. The operator is: swap the 1st and 3rd figures.

question:
Study the following input–output pairs, all produced by a single unknown operator:

[ ■  ●  ▲ ]  →  [ ☐  ○  △ ]
[ ○  ☐  ■ ]  →  [ ●  ■  ☐ ]

Which operator was applied?
options: Invert all shading
Rotate one position to the right
Swap the 1st and 3rd figures
Replace the 1st figure with the last
explanation: In both cases every figure has its shading inverted: ■→☐, ●→○, ▲→△ (and vice versa). The operator inverts all shading.

question:
A panel defines two operators:
• P  rotates the sequence one position to the left  (first item moves to the end)
• Q  inverts all shading  (■ ↔ ☐,  ▲ ↔ △,  ● ↔ ○)

Input:  [ ☐  ■  △ ]  →  Apply  P  then  Q  →  Output: ?
explanation: Step 1 (P): rotate left — first item (☐) moves to end → [ ■  △  ☐ ]. Step 2 (Q): invert all shading — ■→☐, △→▲, ☐→■ → [ ☐  ▲  ■ ].

question:
A panel defines two operators:
• P  rotates the sequence one position to the left  (first item moves to the end)
• Q  inverts all shading  (■ ↔ ☐,  ▲ ↔ △,  ● ↔ ○)

Input:  [ △  ●  ○ ]  →  Apply  Q  then  P  →  Output: ?
explanation: Step 1 (Q): invert all — △→▲, ●→○, ○→● → [ ▲  ○  ● ]. Step 2 (P): rotate left — first item (▲) moves to end → [ ○  ●  ▲ ].

question:
A panel defines three operators:
• ♦  adds a figure: duplicates the last item and appends it to the sequence
• ♣  removes the first figure
• ♠  swaps the 1st and 2nd figures

Input:  [ ▲  ●  ■ ]  →  Apply  ♦  →  Output: ?
explanation: ♦ duplicates the last item (■) and appends it. Result: [ ▲  ●  ■  ■ ].

question:
A panel defines three operators:
• ♦  duplicates and appends the last item
• ♣  removes the first figure
• ♠  swaps the 1st and 2nd figures

Input:  [ ○  △  ☐ ]  →  Apply  ♣  then  ♠  →  Output: ?
explanation: Step 1 (♣): remove 1st (○) → [ △  ☐ ]. Step 2 (♠): swap 1st and 2nd → [ ☐  △ ].

question:
Study the sequence and identify the pattern:

Position 1:  ■  ▲  ●
Position 2:  ☐  ▲  ●
Position 3:  ■  △  ●
Position 4:  ☐  △  ●
Position 5:  ■  ▲  ○
Position 6:  ?
explanation: Figure 1 alternates ■/☐ every step. Figure 2 alternates ▲/△ every 2 steps. Figure 3 alternates ●/○ every 4 steps. At position 6: figure 1 = ☐, figure 2 = ▲, figure 3 = ○. Result: [ ☐  ▲  ○ ].

question:
A process applies an unknown operator to produce the following results:

[ ■  ●  ▲  ○ ]  →  [ ■  ●  ▲ ]
[ △  ☐  ■  ● ]  →  [ △  ☐  ■ ]
[ ○  ▲  ●  ☐ ]  →  [ ○  ▲  ● ]

Which operator was applied?
options: Remove the last figure
Remove the first figure
Swap the 1st and last figures
Invert all shading
explanation: In all three cases, the last figure is removed from the sequence. The operator is: remove the last figure.

question:
A process applies an unknown single operator. Identify it from these pairs:

[ ▲  ●  ■ ]  →  [ ▲  ■  ● ]
[ ☐  △  ○ ]  →  [ ☐  ○  △ ]
[ ●  ■  ▲ ]  →  [ ●  ▲  ■ ]

Which operator was applied?
options: Swap the 2nd and 3rd figures
Swap the 1st and 2nd figures
Rotate one position to the right
Invert all shading
explanation: In all three cases, the 1st figure is unchanged while the 2nd and 3rd swap. The operator is: swap the 2nd and 3rd figures.
